Award.AwardTitle: Santa Fe Conference on Rock Magnetism
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is for partial support to hold a Conference on Rock Magnetism and its Applications, June 6-9, 2019 in Santa Fe NM, continuing a biennial series of such conferences. St. John?s College will serve as the venue. The award will provide partial coverage of expenses, particularly for students and early career participants. The broad goal of the Santa Fe Conference series is to bring together present and future leaders in the field for in-depth discussion of fundamental aspects of rock and mineral magnetism, and applications in global geophysics, tectonics, extraterrestrial magnetism, and surficial environmental studies; these discussions are intended to be more intensive, interactive and sustained than is possible under the format of large society meetings. Broader impacts of this activity include: (1) transdisciplinary and interdisciplinary communication to foster new approaches to geoscience problems involving iron minerals and their use as paleomagnetic field recorders and as indicators of paleoenvironmental conditions and Earth processes; and (2) the development of young scientists by providing the opportunity to meet and interact with leading international researchers, gain a deeper understanding and broader perspective, and form the basis for future cross-disciplinary collaborations.

One explicit aim of the 2019 conference is to explore short-term (decadal to millennial) variations in the geomagnetic field, their records in natural and archeological materials, and their effects on the production of radionuclides such as 10Be and 14C in the Earth?s atmosphere. Plenary speakers include a leading expert in cosmogenic nuclides . Another key objective is to examine the new understanding of stable remanence in nonuniformly magnetized grains that is being achieved through novel approaches to magnetic microscopy and numerical micromagnetic modeling. The meeting includes a full-day workshop on modeling of magnetic microstructures using the MERRILL software, including a keynote presentation, discussion of the state-of-the-art by leading experts, and hands-on exercises that will teach workshop participants how to apply advanced modeling in their own research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organized by the faculty and staff of the University of Minnesota's Institute for Rock Magnetism, the 11th Biennial Santa Fe Conference on Rock Magnetism was held June 6-9, 2019 on the campus of St. John's College in Santa Fe, New Mexico, and was attended by fifty US and international scientists as well as graduate students. The broad goal of the Santa Fe Conference series is to bring together present and future leaders in rock magnetism, paleomagnetism and related fields for in-depth discussion of fundamental aspects of rock and mineral magnetism, as well as applications in global geophysics, tectonics, extraterrestrial magnetism, and surficial environmental studies. These meetings are designed to allow collaborative exploration of the state of the art in magnetic geophysics and its applications throughout the natural sciences (including environmental science, geobiology, mineral physics and others), in an informal, interactive discussion-oriented mode. Ultimately the purpose is to advance our ability to understand the evolution of the Earth's deep interior and its surface environments, by analyzing the information stored in the magnetically-ordered Iron minerals contained in rocks and sediments.

Frontier research areas covered in half-day sessions in the 2019 conference included: (1) Fundamental rock magnetism, micromagnetic modeling and imaging of micromagnetic structures; (2) Methods of mathematical analysis for magnetic experimental results on natural materials; (3) Signatures of environmental processes in magnetic properties of sediments, and (4) Decadal to millennial time variations in the paleomagnetic field.  Besides the technical sessions, a one day specialized workshop was held to explore numerical modeling of micromagnetic structures within individual particles of magnetic minerals; such microstructures respond to external magnetic field conditions, and they encode past geomagnetic field conditions as well as helping to control the particle-size dependent behavior observed in lab experiments.  The workshop was organized in order to make new software tools more accessible to the rock magnetic community and promote the adaptation of best practices.

Each of these research areas is the subject of sustained and intensive study by research groups around the world. Naturally, the ultimate solutions to the problems outlined above still remain to be discovered, but focused gatherings of leading International and interdisciplinary researchers and students, like this meeting, constitute a very important part of the process of discovery. In this context, the Santa Fe Conference helps advance the state of the art in magnetic geophysics and its Earth-science applications.
